 I have a good friend who has said to me on several occassions:" I am Christian, but I'm not so emersed that I am not willing to accept that everything I believe to be true just might be wrong."

I am posting here because I have a problem which I feel guilty about. Maybe someone knows the answer.
 
 My best mate at school has just told me he is gay. We are boarders and share a room, and he hasn't hit on me or anything like that, but he keeps telling me he likes me. I like him too, but I don't like boys in that way. So I don't know what to say when he says things like that. I just don't say anything and he goes all quiet.
 
 We have known each other for a long time (since we were six, and I will be fourteen next month) and we are good mates, so I don't want to hurt him. But it is very difficult, now he has told me, as some of my other friends say that they know all about him, (I never told them,) and that the whole school will think I am gay also, if I keep hanging out with him.
 
 I could ask to go to another room, but he would wonder why, and anyway someone else would have to swap with me. We have been sharing most of our time at school, and no one has said anything to me. I know I shouldn't care, because I am cool about gays, but it still seems to worry me. Maybe I should do nothing, does anyone know?
 
 Leo

Leo,
 kudos on sticking by your mate and friend. He could have a crush on you, but those things pass. I had such a crush on one of my friends growing up. We are still friends today and I am 35 as of yesterday. It passes. Be honest, communicate your feelings in honest ways using "I" statements. example:
 "I" feel you might be readin into this and "I" want us to talk about things. "I" am straight. "I" feel like you are hoping "I" am gay and "I" am not.
 
 It's hard to come out to friends and puts one in an wierd place. Stand your ground, be you, talk him through it, when he needs to talk. 
 
 Who cares if people think you are gay, it doesn't really matter what others think. You know the truth and that is all that counts. Think how he feels when people know he is gay. It can be fearful at times. I would be happy to answer any question or anything that could help you!

Leo:
 
 Another good way to respond to your best friend when he says things that might make you feel uncomfortable, is to simply say: Thank you. 
 
 I also find humor, as long as it's good natured, can smooth rough edges in a multitude of situations.

 He is actually a great guy, a fantastic soccer player - much better than me, and I don't want to stop being friends with him. Also, he is a year older than me, and much bigger, and when I first came to the school he protected me from the bullies, so I guess I owe him. 
 
 He didn't make a big deal about it either, he just said that because we were best mates, he wanted me to know. 
 
 I am only a little scared that if I tell him that I like him also, (which I do,) he might expect me to do things with him. I don't think I can do that, and then we would not be friends any more. And I don't want that to happen.
 
 But I would never stop hanging out with him just cos of what others think. Whatever happens he has been a good mate for all my time at school. My mum likes him, and she approves of our friendship, (and you wouldn't believe how bossy and picky my mum can be!) and he stays at our place during the Christmas hols. 
 
 I want to talk to him about being gay, cos I don't really understand how he can fancy another guy, but I am scared of offending him. If I tell him I don't understand it, it makes him sound like a freak or something. I think it must be terrible for him to be different from everyone else. 
 
 But there is a funny side to this. When we go into town together, all the chicks are falling over him, and they never give me a second look. LOL!

The bottom line is this . . . 
 
 Most people, when they talk about choosing not to be gay, aren't even talking about choosing against or for a certain sexual orientation. They are talking about choosing against actions that gay people do--namely pursuing romantic a/or sexual relationships with people of the same gender. That is not to say that there are not still those who do argue from the standpoint of "changing one's orientation," but that is not really the issue in most cases. It is one of changing one's actions.
 
 To argue as if many gay rights opponents are trying to get gays to leave their sexual orientation is really somewhat intellectually dishonest. A better way to say it is that they are arguing that it is better not to pursue those actions. You can agree with them or disagree, but let's at least be honest about their message.
 
 It's true that some still hold to the idea that orientation can be changed, but that is getting pretty rare. Even NARTH and groups like that are focused on encouraging people to change their actions. "Ex-gays" are really just people who have stopped pursuing gay relationships. 
 
 A lot of it depends on one's worldview. If someone is determined to hold to the idea that we as humans are beholden to some vague psychological concept called "sexual orientation" (which is being held up as doctrinal dogma by gay rights groups), as well as catagorize people into easy little boxes called gay, bi, and straight, then they are probably never going to view homosexuality as anything other than a matter of nature. I tend to define "being gay" or "straight" by what one does--if they pursue same-gender relationships, then that is being gay, period.
 
 If "gay" is genetic or is nature, then I would agree it can't be changed. But that is beside the point. Actions can always be changed. Now if you don't want to change them, it is your choice. No one is going to make you.
